metadata.title: Graphene/conducting polymer nano-composite loaded screen printed carbon sensor for simultaneous determination of dopamine and 5-hydroxytryptamine

raphene/conducting polymer nano-composite loaded screen printed arbon sensor for simultaneous determination of dopamine and -hydroxytryptamine
amta Raj a, Pankaj Gupta a, Rajendra N. Goyal a,∗, Yoon-Bo Shim b,∗
Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee 247667, India Department of Chemistry, Pusan National University, Busan 609 735, Republic of Korea
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 20 June 2016 eceived in revised form 5 August 2016 ccepted 15 August 2016 vailable online 16 August 2016
eywords: creen printed carbon electrode
a b s t r a c t
A novel and sensitive electrochemical method has been developed for the simultaneous determination of dopamine (DA) and 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) using graphene (GR) and poly 4-amino-3-hydroxy1-naphthalenesulfonic acid modified screen printed carbon sensor. The electrochemical measurements were studied using cyclic voltammetry, square wave voltammetry, whereas the surface morphology of the modified sensor was characterized by Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy and Field Emission scanning electron microscopy. The fabricated sensor facilitated the analysis of DA and 5-HT in the concentration range 0.05–100 M and 0.05–150 M with the detection limit of 2 nM and 3 nM respectively.
oltammetry eurotransmitters ric acid ryptophan
The fabricated sensor has been explored for the determination of 5-HT in the plasma samples and the selectivity of the proposed work has been proved by the analysis of DA and 5-HT in the presence of common metabolites present in biological fluids. The analytical applicability of the fabricated sensor has also been successfully demonstrated for the simultaneous detection of DA and 5-HT in the pharmacological formulations, human urine and blood samples.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
. Introduction
Nano-materials have attracted tremendous attention in recent ears due to their unique physical, structural and electronic properies [1,2]. Graphene (GR) has been considered as a topic of intense esearch because of its excellent and distinct properties, such as ood electrical and thermal conductivity, high specific surface area, reat mechanical strength, impressive biocompatibility, remarkble mobility of charge carriers, and electrical conductivity. GR s a single-atom thick, extensively conjugated two dimensional arbonaceous nano-material with sp2 hybridized carbon atoms ttached in a six membered arrangement through weak – interctions [3,4]. In addition, the application of conducting polymer or modification of the surface of the electrode has been found o increase electrical conductivity, great chemical stability, better
agnetic property, high electronic affinities, optical properties and ow ionization potential [5]. Conducting polymer of 4-amino-3ydroxy-1-naphthalenesulfonic acid (AHNSA) has been used with
∗ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: rngcyfcy@gmail.com, rngcyfcy@iitr.ac.in (R.N. Goyal), bshim@pusan.ac.kr (Y.-B. Shim).
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.snb.2016.08.083 925-4005/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
GR to overcome the aggregation of graphene sheets and enhance stability and sensitivity [6]. The use of conducting polymer for the surface modification on one hand increases the conductivity of the surface, whereas, on the other hand the synergistic interaction between AHNSA polymer and graphene via – stacking interaction causes a large net stabilized structure, shorter ion diffusion paths and - interaction that encourages the electron transport [6,7].
Screen-printed carbon sensors (SPCs) have attracted enormous attention of researchers in the recent years due to their superiority over the common sensors as they are field-based size, portable, simple in fabrication and cost effective. As SPCs are less expensive they can be easily replaced after each run. SPCs have a very small working area which is highly suitable for the trace volume of determining species. SPCs are simple to operate, reliable and provide high sensitivity, better selectivity and good reproducibility [8,9].
Dopamine [4-(2-aminoethyl) benzene-1,2-diol, DA] is the predominant catecholamine neuro-transmitter and has been extensively found in the tissues of mammalian brain and plays a significant role as a modulator of hormone secretion, cardio-vascular function, renal function, catecholamine release, vascular tone and gastrointestinal motility in mammals. Some other physiological functions, such as, motivation and reward, control the movement

94 M. Raj et al. / Sensors and A
f information in the brain, voluntary movement are also regulated y this catecholamine [10–12]. Dysregulation of dopaminergic ransmission has been associated with neurological disorders like arkinson’s disease, Schizophrenia, Tourette’s syndrome and many ore [13,14]. DA also performs as a biochemical precursor of other atecholamine neurotransmitters norepinephrine and epinephrine 15]. The determination of DA has been considered useful in the iagnosis of several diseases and hence makes it the choice of bioogically and pharmacologically oriented research. Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT), is a biogenic
onoamine neurotransmitter and neuromodulator [16] found in he human brain [17], which plays a pivotal role to control and reglate various physiological functions such as eating disorder, sleep, uscle contraction, sexual activity and thermoregulation as well s in psychopathological processes such as anxiety disorder, liver egeneration, infantile autism, alcoholism, obsessive-compulsive isorder and drug dependency [5,18]. 5-HT is synthesized in uman system from an essential amino acid tryptophan by the nzyme tryptophan hydroxylase − I (TpH-1) and widely disributed in the central and peripheral nervous systems, smooth
uscles, and platelets in the body. The large amount is localized n the enterochromaffin (EC) cells of gastrointestinal tract; (∼90% f the whole 5-HT content of the body), whereas, platelets contain ∼8%), and the rest amount is located in brain (central nervous ystem ∼1%) [19]. 5-HT is involved in several gastrointestinal isorders including secretion, irritable bowel syndrome, food ypersensitivity and inflammatory bowel disease [20].
Research demonstrates that the respective release of DA and -HT influence each other [21]. Thus, simultaneous determination f DA and 5-HT is of considerable importance, since both coexists
n the biological systems. Several analytical methodologies have een developed for the simultaneous determination of DA and 5- T in the pharmaceutical and biological samples including HPLC 22], liquid chromatography [23], capillary electrophoresis [24], everse-phase ion-pair HPLC with electrochemical detection [25], LC [26] and mass spectrometry [27]. DA has also been studied t conducting polymer modified surfaces, whereas, little attenion has been paid to 5-HT [28,29]. However, these methods have arious limitations, such as poor selectivity and sensitivity, large nalysis time and requirement of expensive instrumentation, thus here is need of a rapid, accurate and more sensitive technique. lectrochemical techniques are feasible for the estimation of elecroactive compounds due to the advantages such as high sensitivity, etter selectivity, low-cost apparatus, accuracy, ease of instruent, rapid response, simplicity and remarkable reproducibility 30,31]. The simultaneous measurement of these neurotransmiters is remained a challenge due to the inability of most of the lectrodes to separate the oxidation potentials of these two species ignificantly enough to allow their accurate determination.
In this manuscript, the simultaneous determination of DA and -HT was investigated in human biological fluids and pharmaco-
ogical formulations by using graphene and p-AHNSA composite odified Screen-printed carbon sensor (SPCs). The fabricated senor was able to sense and separate the two analytes from the ommon interfering electro-active species present in biological amples. The proposed method is simple and has low detection imits, which indicate the superiority of this technique over the
ethods reported in the recent years.
. Experimental
.1. Instrumentation
Bio analytical system voltammetric analyzer (Epsilon EC-USB, SA) was employed in all the voltammetric experiments. Screen
rs B 239 (2017) 993–1002
printed carbon (SPCs) sensor having all in one electrodes was used for the electrochemical experiments. For the screen printing of the SPCs, carbon and silver inks (Jujo Chemical, Japan) were used. The polystyrene-based film was used to print the working electrode (area = 0.07 cm2) by using BANDO Industrial, Korea, screen printer. In the SPCs, GR/p-AHNSA modified working electrode, an Ag/AgCl (3 M NaCl) (Model MF-2052 RB-5B) as a reference electrode and carbon was used as a counter electrode. The pH of the phosphate buffers was measured using Thermo Fisher Scientific, Singapore Digital pH meter (Eutech Instruments, model pH 700). The surface morphology of the unmodified and modified sensors was characterized by using Zeiss ultra plus 55, Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopic (EIS) measurements were performed using a galvanostat (model; Versastat 3, PAR).
2.2. Reagents
Dopamine (DA), 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT), tryptophan (Trp), 4-amino-3-hydroxy-1-naphthalenesulfonic acid, ascorbic acid (AA), uric acid (UA) and graphite powder ( < 20 nm) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA). For the preparation of phosphate buffers in the pH range 2.4-10.0 ( = 0.1 M), the chemical were obtained from E. Merck (India) Ltd. Mumbai. The analytical grade solvents and chemicals were used throughout the experiments.
2.3. Preparation of GR/p-AHNSA modified SPCs
The improved Hummers method was used to synthesize GR from the graphite [32]. Powder XRD and Raman spectroscopic were apply to characterization the GR and the results were obtained as reported earlier [30,33]. Before using the SPCs for recording the voltammograms, a drop of 0.1 M FeCl3 solution was touched at the reference electrode. This procedure oxidized Ag into Ag/AgCl to avoid any interference of Ag particles in the experimental studies. Now cyclic voltammogram was used to scan the electrode between the potential ranges of −200 mV to +600 mV in 0.1 M HNO3, where no peak was observed which confirmed the absence of Ag particle at SPCs. The suspension of the graphene at a concentration of 0.7 mg mL−1 was prepared in a mixture of double distilled water and DMF (1: 9). The optimum amount of graphene (6 L) was dropped onto the surface of the working electrode of SPCs and then SPCs were kept in an oven at 50–60 ◦C for 30 min to dry. The GR modified SPCs was dipped in a solution containing 2 mM of AHNSA in 0.1 M nitric acid solution and the polymeric layer was grown by scanning the potentials three times from −0.8 V to +2.0 V at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1. The obtained polymer modified surface was rinsed with double distilled water and was characterized with the help of FE-SEM.
2.4. Voltammetric procedure and sample preparation
Stock solutions of 1 mM L−1of DA and 5-HT were prepared in a required amount of double distilled water. For the preparation of the standard concentration of analytes, desired volume of the analyte solution was added to the electrochemical cell containing 2 mL of phosphate buffer (pH = 7.2) as a supporting electrolyte. Double distilled water was used to make the final volume of 4 mL. The square wave voltammetric parameters were optimized as follows: initial potential (E): 0 mV, final potential (E):800 mV, square wave amplitude (Esw): 25 mV, potential step (E): 4 mV and square wave frequency (f): 15 Hz. All the potentials are reported with respect to the Ag/AgCl electrode at an ambient temperature of 25 ± 2 ◦C. After each run the SCE was discarded and a new electrode was taken.
The commercially available DA tablets obtained from the medical store of Roorkee were grounded into fine powder in a pestle

nd mortar. Then 200 mg of the pharmaceutical formulations was uitably diluted with water and buffer solution of pH 7.2, so that he concentrations of analytes reached in the working concentraion range. The proposed technique was used to determine the rug in the respective pharmaceutical formulations under similar onditions which were used to obtain the concentration graph.
The human biological samples (Urine and blood) of the healthy olunteers were received from the hospital of IIT Roorkee. Now he plasma was separated from the blood samples by centrifugaion at 2000 rpm for 5 min at 4 ◦C using EDTA as the anticoagulant. he yellowish part (plasma) was used to analyze the concentration f DA and 5-HT. Urine and plasma samples were suitably diluted ith phosphate buffer to minimize matrix complexity. The stanard addition method was applied to calculate the concentration f both analytes DA and 5-HT.
. Results and discussion
.1. Characterization of GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs
The characterization of the surface of unmodified, graphene odified and GR/p-AHNSA nanocomposite modified SPCs was done
sing FE-SEM and obtained microscopic images are presented in ig. 1. In the unmodified SPCs, only a film of the carbon used in he construction of the working electrode was noticed, whereas, eposition of the GR as flakes on SPCs surface was clearly noticed n the case of graphene modified SPCs as shown in Fig. 1A and B, espectively. The microscopic image of the GR-polymer nanocomosite film (Fig. 1C) showed that the p-(AHNSA) was amassed on he SPCs surface with nano-rod shape particles intertwined with R and formed a porous, crystalline and etched surface. It can be een that the nanocomposite network was constructed uniformly hroughout the surface, and provided a larger electroactive surface rea in comparison to the unmodified sensor and promoted a facile lectron transfer across the film efficiently.
The electron-transfer resistance (RCT) corresponding to unmodied, graphene modified and GR/p-AHNSA nanocomposite modified PCs surfaces was calculated by using EIS. The experiment was arried out in 1:1 mixture of 0.1 M KCl and 5 mM K3Fe(CN)6 soluion over the frequency range 100 kHz to 10 mHz at a potential f 0.05 V. The resulting Nyquist plots observed for the unmodied, graphene modified SPCs and GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs are shown n Fig. 2. After modification of the SPCs surface with GR and R/p-AHNSA film, the RCT values decreased in comparison to the nmodified surface of SPCs. As shown, the diameter of semicirle gets reduced for GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs, implying a facile electron ransfer at the redox probes in the electrolyte solution. Whereas, at nmodified SPCs, the resistance to charge transport value increases
(C) GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. The inset represents the Randle’s equivalent circuit used for data fitting.
substantially and restrained the pathways for electron transfer. The value of RCT for the redox process was calculated by fitting the Randle’s circuit (inset of Fig. 2) and was found to be 2790 , 860 and 260 for the unmodified SPCs, GR/SPCs and GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs, respectively.
3.2. Cyclic voltammetric studies
Cyclic voltammograms for a mixture of 50 M DA and 5-HT in pH 7.2 phosphate buffer at unmodified SPCs, GR/SPCs and GR/pAHNSA/SPCs are recorded at a scan rate of 100 mVs−1 and are shown in Fig. 3. The voltammogram of the mixture of DA and 5- HT shows broad and overlapped indefinable peaks (curve a) at an unmodified electrode as shown in Fig. 3. While at the surface of GR/SPCs, two well-defined voltammetric peaks (curve b) at about ∼180 mV (Ia) and ∼378 mV (IIb) corresponding to the oxidation of DA and 5-HT were observed, respectively. However, at the GR/pAHNSA/SPCs, the peak current has greatly increased with negative shift in the peak current at ∼146 mV(I’a) and ∼342 mV (II’b) for the oxidation of DA and 5-HT, respectively. The oxidation peak of DA also formed a quasi-reversible couple with peak at ∼90 mV (Ia) at GR/SPCs and at ∼48 mV (I’a) at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. The oxidation peaks (Ia and I’a) were observed due to the oxidation of DA to o-dopaminequinone and the cathodic peak ((Ib and I’b) pointing the reduction of dopaminequinone back to dopamine as reported

arlier [34]. The enhanced peaks current with negative shift in the eak potential indicated that the composite of GR and p-AHNSA film ccelerates the kinetics of the electrochemical oxidation of both DA nd 5-HT.
To clarify the nature of the electrode transfer process, scan rate v) studies were carried out. The anodic peak current was found to ncrease with increasing scan rate and the linearity of ip versus v nd ip versus log (v) for DA and 5-HT are obtained in the scan rate ange of 5–150 mV s−1 and can be expressed by the relation:

The linearity of ip versus v and slope value of log ip versus log v (slope > 0.5) reveals the adsorption controlled oxidation for DA and 5-HT [33].
3.3. Square wave voltammetry
3.3.1. Electrochemical investigations of DA The square wave voltammograms in the range of 0.05–100 M concentration of DA were recorded using the GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs in pH 7.2 at the optimal SWV parameters. The results showed that the anodic peak current (ip) increased linearly with the increasing concentration of DA as shown in Fig. 4A. The anodic current values are reported as an average of at least three replicate determinations. The dependence of ip on concentration can be expressed by the equation:
ip( A) = 0.0997[C0.05–100 M] + 0.1815
having correlation coefficients of 0.998, where [C] is the concentration of DA in M. The detection limit and limit of quantification were calculated by using 3 /b, where is the standard deviation of “n”, number of blank voltammograms and b is the slope of calibration plot and was found to be 2 nM.
The electrochemical response of DA was analyzed in the different pH of the supporting electrolyte at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. The pH of the supporting electrolytes influences the oxidation signal of DA. It was observed that at physiological pH 7.1, the highest peak current was observed (Fig. 5A) and with the increasing pH (2.4-10.0), the peak potential (Ep) gradually shifted to the less positive potentials and a linear relation was observed between anodic peak potential (Ep) and pH, which can be represented by the equation:
Ep(pH2.2–10) = −55.421pH + 551.09 mVvs.Ag/AgCl
having correlation coefficient of 0.985. The slope of the (dEP/dpH) plot was 0.055 V and was close to the theoretical Nernstian value of 0.059 V and clearly demonstrated that the equal number of electrons and protons were transferred in the electrochemical oxidation process of DA [30].
Further, the SWVs for DA were also recorded at different square wave frequency using GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. The observed slope (0.998) of log ip vs. log f plot, which was greater than 0.5, suggested the involvement of adsorption controlled electrode reaction.

.3.2. Electrochemical investigations of 5-HT The effect of supporting electrolytes pH on the electro-oxidation f 5-HT at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs was investigated in the pH range .4–10.0. It was observed that the Ep shifted negatively with the
ncrease in the pH of the supporting electrolyte. Also, the maximum eak current was observed at pH 7.2 (Fig. 5B). A linear relationship as observed between Ep and pH, which can be expressed by the quation:
p(pH2.2–10.5) = −39.29pH + 615.83 mVvs.Ag/AgCl
ith a correlation coefficient of 0.988. The obtained slope of the p vs pH (0.039 V/pH), was nearly half to the theoretical Nernstian alue and indicated that number of protons and electrons involved

in the electrode oxidation of 5-HT were unequal. The involvement of one proton and two electron is well reported during the oxidation of 5-HT [5]. The effect of square wave frequency (f) on the voltammetric response of 5-HT was examined in the frequency range 5–40 Hz at GR/P-AHNSA/SPC sensor. From the observed slope value of log ip vs. log f plot (>0.5) further confirmed the involvement of adsorption complications in 5-HT oxidation.
The square wave voltammograms of 5-HT at different concentrations were similarly recorded at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. The peak current (ip) of the anodic peak (after correction of background current) increased with the increase in the concentration of 5-HT at pH 7.2 as depicted in Fig. 4B. he range 0.05–150 M with a correlation coefficient of 0.998. The ependence of ip on concentration can be presented as:

The limit of detection LOD) and limit of quantification (LOQ) for the determination of 5- T were calculated to be 3 nM and 10 nM respectively. As the 5-HT oncentration in healthy human beings is reported in the range of .5–1.4 M [35], the proposed method with lower detection-limit an be applied for the analysis of 5-HT in the biological samples.
.3.3. Simultaneous determination of DA and 5-HT Fig. 6A compares the square wave voltammograms (SWVs) of a
ixture of 50 M DA and 5-HT in pH 7.2 phosphate buffer using nmodified SPCs, GR/SPCs and GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. At unmodified PCs, the oxidation peak current of DA and 5-HT get overlapped nd a broad, poor response at a peak potential of ∼338 mV (curve ) was observed. The obtained result cannot be assigned to DA or 5- T. While in the case of p-AHNSA or GR modified SPCs, two peaks or DA and 5-HT at 160 mV and 365 mV or 150 mV and 340 mV ere observed, respectively. GR modified SPCs displays higher peak urrent with negative shift of peak potential which indicates the lectrocatalytic effect of GR to the oxidation of analytes (curve b). here was virtually little difference in the peak height and peak urrent of DA and 5-HT at these sensors. The use of GR/p-AHNSA omposite SPCs showed two well defined and separated oxidation eaks at around ∼136 mV and ∼325 mV corresponding to the oxiation of DA and 5-HT respectively. The use of GR or AHNSA also eads to the enhancement in the peak currents as well as shift in he peak potential, but the remarkable anodic peak current with hifting of more negative potential observed for the GR/p-AHNSA omposite based SPCs (curve c). The obtained results support the act that the synergic effect of GR and conducting polymer (pHNSA) accelerate the rate of electron transfer and improve the ensitivity of detection [36].
To investigate the simultaneous electrochemical responses of A and 5-HT at the surface of GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs, experiment was xecuted in two steps. In the first set of experiment, the square ave voltammograms recorded for the different concentrations of A while the concentration of 5-HT was kept constant (20 M) re shown in Fig. 6B. It was observed that the oxidation peak curent response of DA increases with the increase in its concentration ithout affecting the 5-HT signal. Similarly, Fig. 6C shows square ave voltammograms obtained by varying the concentration of
.2 phosphate buffer solution containing 20 M DA and [UA]: (a) 100; (b) 800; (c) (d) 200 and (e) 250 M observed at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs in pH 7.2 phosphate buffer
5-HT keeping the concentration DA constant (10 M). It was found that the anodic peak current of 5-HT increased linearly while the voltammetric peak of DA was practically unchanged without affecting the peak current and peak shape. Thus, the results concluded that both compounds can be determined in presence of each other without affecting in the oxidation peak current and peak shape. The dependence of the peak current with concentration in mixture solutions is identical to the individual voltammetric study of both analytes.
3.4. Interference study
Selectivity is an important indicator for the practical measurement due to presence of various interfering substances in the biological fluids. The high concentration of common metabolites such as uric acid, ascorbic acid, xanthine etc. present in biological fluids may interfere with the electrochemical signal of DA and 5- HT and consequently affect the selectivity. In these studies, it can be seen that the DA and 5-HT will not interfere with each other at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs surface as the oxidation potentials of DA and 5-HT are about 400 mV apart. The interference with major electroactive biological components such as ascorbic acid (AA) and uric acid (UA), which commonly oxidize at potentials similar to DA and 5-HT, has been studied by recording the voltammograms at GR/pAHNSA/SPCs using SWV. Initially, at the fix concentration of DA (20 M) and 5-HT (10 M) and with increasing concentration of AA SWVs were recorded. It was found that the AA did not interfere upto 1 mM concentration in the determination of DA and 5-HT as the oxidation potential of AA was close to zero volt.
In another experiment, the effect of UA was examined on 20 M DA. Fig. 7 presents the SWVs corresponding to the oxidation of 20 M DA with increasing concentration of UA (Fig. 7A). Two well separate oxidation peaks at the potential of ∼115 and ∼440 mV were observed for DA and UA, respectively. Up to 2 mM concentration of UA did not shows any substantial changes in oxidation peak current of DA, thus, indicating the oxidation of DA free from the interference of UA. Similarly the SWVs were also recorded to investigate the interference effect of UA on 10 M 5-HT. The result indicate that upto 50 M UA did not affect the oxidation signal of 5-HT, however, at higher concentrations of UA, the 5-HT oxidation peak became broaden. Thus, it was concluded that UA was tolerated upto five times concentration of 5-HT. When interference of UA was examined in the mixture of DA and 5-HT, again it was noticed that DA remained unaffected up to 2 mM concentration of UA, where as

he 5- HT peak tolerated only up to 50 M UA, after which serious nterference was observed.
The concentration of 5-HT in mammalian brain is fairly related o tryptophan (Trp) concentration because Trp is the key ingredint in making 5-HT. At a simplistic level, it could be thought of as a arent-child relationship, with tryptophan being the parent. Thus, ue to their close relation and importance in human physiology, he electrochemical study of both analytes has also been carried ut. Fig. 7 B shows the SWVs at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs in the mixture f 10 M of 5-HT and different concentrations of Trp at pH 7.2. rom the results, it was observed that Trp did not influence the xidation signal of 5-HT and a well-defined peak separation was lso observed. Hence, it was concluded that the proposed electrohemical sensor provide the selective method which can be used ffectively for the determination of DA and 5-HT in human biologcal fluids having various possible interferents.
.5. Stability and reproducibility of GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs
The studies on long term stability were not possible because PCs were used only for one run and then was changed. owever, sensor to sensor variation was monitored for eight GR/pHNSA/SPCs. The electrochemical experiment was executed in a olution having, DA (20 M) and 5-HT (50 M) at pH 7.2. The xperimental results demonstrated that up to 2–3 scanned at all he modified SPCs a negligible variation in the oxidation current esponse was observed, From the calculations, relative standard eviation (RSD) were found to be 2.12% and 2.47% for DA and 5- T respectively. The results concluded that the sensor to sensor ariation bear appreciable reproducibility. After 2–3 scanned, a sigificant decrease in the oxidation peak current of analytes was bserved at the surface of GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. Hence, to get the eproducible results the modified SPCs was changed after 2 runs.
.6. Analytical applicability
.6.1. Pharmaceutical analysis The practical applicability of the developed sensor was valuated for the determination of DA in three commercial
pharmaceutical samples. The required amounts of pharmaceutical samples were suitably powdered and diluted with pH 7.2 buffer to bring the concentration of the drug in the working range. The SWVs were then recorded at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs and with help of calibration plot DA content in the various pharmaceutical preparations was then ascertained. From the results, it can be observed that the calculated results were found to be in good agreement with the labeled amount. The obtained results suggesting that determination of DA in pharmaceutical preparations using proposed method is precise and convenient (Table 1).
3.6.2. Real sample assay The accuracy of the present methodology was also investigated by applying it for the detection of DA and 5-HT in biological fluids, like plasma and urine. The samples were prepared following the procedure as discussed in section 2.4. Two times diluted plasma sample was used to record the SWVs, and a bump at Ep (300 mV), corresponding to the oxidation of 5-HT was observed. Now the further studies in the same solution were performed by spiking the exogenous 5-HT and then SWVs were recorded. The standard addition plot (Fig. 8) was used to calculate the concentration of 5-HT in the plasma sample and was detected as 1.6 M (Table 2). The negative intercept on X-axis is insignificant. The% recovery value observed in the range of 98.1–101.2% is summarized in Table 2.
An attempt to determine DA in the plasma sample of normal person was then made, however, no peak for DA was observed in 2 times diluted plasma samples, as the discharged concentration of DA in a normal person is reported in the range of 10−10 to 10−12 M. Therefore, the recovery experiments were carried out by spiking the known DA in plasma samples. The concentrations of DA were

GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs. To reduce the matrix complexity, the filtered urine samples were diluted 10 times with pH 7.2 buffer. Now the diluted samples were spiked with different concentrations of both the analytes and then SWVs were recorded. The obtained peak current values were used to calculate the concentration of DA and 5-HT by using the regression equation. The observed values for DA and 5-HT in the urine samples are summarized in Table 4 showing recovery in the range of 98.6-100.38% with R.S.D of ±2.17% (n = 3). The catecholamines and 5-HT concentration have been found to increase in the patients suffering from carcinoid syndrome, Parkinson and hypertension. The detection limits of the proposed method is in nM level, hence, both the compounds can be easily determined at GR/p-AHNSA/SPCs in such patients without any interference from the metabolites present in the blood and urine.

M. Raj et al. / Sensors and A
To validate the results observed for 5-HT in plasma by using R/p-AHNSA/SPCs with some standard method, UV spectrum of 5- T was recorded at pH 7.2. A well −defined absorption peak at 75 nm was observed. Using the standard addition method, the oncentration of 5-HT in plasma sample was found to be 1.56 M. he significant results observed by the two different techniques ere also confirmed by the paired t-test. The calculated and tabuated t-test values were −1.671 and 4.303 observed, respectively, hich are under a confidence limit of 95%. The insignificant differnce between the investigated data by the two methods proves the alidity of the proposed technique.
. Conclusion
The proposed protocol deals with the fabrication of a novel elecrochemical sensor for simultaneous determination of DA and 5-HT ased on graphene and p-AHNSA disposable SPCs. The proposed ethod provides a simple, sensitive, selective, rapid and inexpenive detection of DA and 5-HT in human biological samples. In the eveloped sensor, the functional groups rich polymer film and the ynergistic interaction between p-AHNSA and graphene via – tacking interaction encourages the electron transfer and showed
remarkable electrocatalytic activity toward neurotransmitters, A and 5-HT. For both the analytes an increase in the peak cur-
ent and shift of oxidation potentials to less positive values was bserved. A low detection limit and high sensitivity of the proosed technique in comparison to the recently reported literatures

Biographies
Mamta Raj did her Masters in 2012 from Malviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur. She is working as Junior Research Fellow of Univeristy Grants Commission, New Delhi.
Pankaj Gupta did his M.Sc from Malviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, in 2011. Presently he is working as Senior Research Fellow financed by Ministry of Human Resources, New Delhi
Rajendra N Goyal obtained Ph.D. in 1975 from Roorkee University and D.Sc. from Agra University, India in 1991. He worked as postdoctoral fellow at University of Oklahoma, Norman, USA during 1979–1982 and again during 1989–1991. He was British Council fellow at University of Loughborough, UK during 1979 and was visiting professor at Kyoto University, Japan during 2007. He was JSPS fellowship recipient in years 2003 and 2014. Presently Dr. Goyal is working as Professor in Department of Chemistry, I.I.T. Roorkee, Roorkee, India. His current research area includes molecular electrochemistry, electrochemistry at nano-material modified electrodes and sensors and biosensors for doping agents.
Yoon-Bo Shim received his Ph.D. in Department of Chemistry at Pusan National University, South Korea, in 1985. He is working as a professor at Department of Chemistry and a director at Institute of BioPhysio Sensor Technology (IBST), Pusan
biological, organic species with modified electrodes, electron transfer of organic compounds and proteins on the biomembranes, and characterization of conducting polymers and their applications

metadata.abstractText: A novel and sensitive electrochemical method has been developed for the simultaneous determination of dopamine (DA) and 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) using graphene (GR) and poly 4-amino-3-hydroxy1-naphthalenesulfonic acid modified screen printed carbon sensor. The electrochemical measurements were studied using cyclic voltammetry, square wave voltammetry, whereas the surface morphology of the modified sensor was characterized by Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy and Field Emission scanning electron microscopy. The fabricated sensor facilitated the analysis of DA and 5-HT in the concentration range 0.05–100 M and 0.05–150 M with the detection limit of 2 nM and 3 nM respectively.
